Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Broadening Participation in Computer Science: Using Technology to Accelerate Collective Impact

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Personalized learning applications can guide students for achievement that connects a broad partnership ecosystem and links students with work-based learning experiences. The proposed conference titled "Broadening Participation in Computer Science: Using Technology to Accelerate Collective Impact" will bring together regional constituents in order to share early project results. This work will be used to develop, unite and leverage the partners and stakeholders necessary to scale students' engagement into computing as well as align the interests of the regional invitees from corporations, foundations, educational institutions, government, and non-profits. Conference attendees will all receive a conference final report summarizing the key findings from each conference session in order to help them make improvements in the intentionality of their programs, partnerships and resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Curated Pathways to Innovation™ uncovers and resolves systemic inequity and inaccessibility in efforts and activities to broaden participation in Computer Science by increasing awareness, interest, and preparation to close the education and prosperity gap for women and underrepresented minorities. Curated Pathways illuminates systemic reasons why current interventions are not working and provides a STEM pathway by connecting otherwise disparate services and interventions that is culturally and gender responsive and centered on equity and student choice with capacity for longitudinal tracking. Curated Pathways puts students at the center with agency for their own pathway.  Powered by artificial intelligence and machine learning, Curated Pathways supports more youth in choosing computing careers by leveraging technology as a solution and taking a whole child centered approach by encouraging self-exploration, self-confidence, motivation and self-esteem. Students become aware of computer science careers, build up their interest, and begin skill preparation. This game changing innovation builds a supportive ecosystem that uplifts women and underrepresented minorities into STEM and computer science careers that moves us closer to closing the education and prosperity gap.

 During this award period, Curated Pathways has engaged over 2700 middle and high school students, and increased interest in computing careers from near zero to 46%. (Compare this result to local and national College Board stats indicating just 2.9-3.9% of students taking the PSAT/SAT are interested in computing majors.) Within the platform, 98% of participating students moved from awareness to interest phase, 84% of students moved from interest to preparation phase, and 36% of participants reported an improvement in their self-efficacy towards working with computers. Females’ positive attitudes in computer programming were sustained through middle school showing that Curated Pathways is preventing their discouragement and attrition in pursuing STEM and computer science futures.

The free activities recommended to students have been sourced from local and national offerings that is mapped to national standards (Computer Science Teacher Association Standards, Next Generation Science Standards, and Common Core Mathematics Standards), to form the basis of an ecosystem and continuum of program interventions. Academically designed longitudinal research and automation within the app produces outcomes data that reports real-time student progress, results, and needs. Content is designed for age ranges grades 5-14, and the platform supports college readiness, retention and career readiness.  Educators were on boarded in less than one hour of orientation training, and the Curated Pathways teacher portal and dashboard provide educators with real time insight on student learning.

Curated Pathways has delivered positive results to address the broadening participation challenge. Research shows that Curated Pathways is increasing students’ motivation and aspiration in pursuit of computing and STEM, and sustaining it for girls, when national research shows student interest in computer science steeply declines, particularly for underrepresented minorities and girls, in the same age/grade levels.  Moreover, the findings suggest that underrepresented minority students tended to have a greater improvement in both their perceived knowledge and interest in computer science during the intervention. For students with lower initial math identity and self-efficacy, there was a greater rate of growth in career aspirations and interest, suggesting the closing of certain disparities. Students who knew more about computer science at the beginning of the intervention were more likely to complete activities, which suggests a greater initial focus on awareness may actually instill longer-term interest and persistence in Computer Science.

 The recent pandemic has underscored the racial and gender inequities prevalent in the U.S. BIPOC work mostly in the service industry and have higher rates of COVID-19 infections and deaths than any other demographics and women have been the most affected by the high unemployment rate with $5.4 million jobs lost since February 2020 and $2.4 million dropping out of labor force entirely (National Women’s Law Center). Understanding how to increase motivation and persistence for females and underrepresented minorities in computer science and providing effective solutions backed by scientific data is critical not only to contributing to 21st Century workforce demands but also to provide attainable career opportunities that break the cycle of generational poverty and lifts up those that have been the most marginalized to power the U.S. economy.
